t: Matthew 21
Jesus Comes to Jerusalem as King
As*p they approached Jerusalem and came to Bethphage on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples,

saying to them, “Go*r to*r the*r village*r ahead*r of*r you,*r and*r at*r once*r you*r will*r find*r a*r donkey*r tied*r there,*r with*r her*r colt*r by*r her.*r Untie*r them*r and*r bring*r them*r to*r me.*r
If*r anyone*r says*r anything*r to*r you,*r say*r that*r the*r Lord*r needs*r them,*r and*r he*r will*r send*r them*r right*r away.”*r
This*p took place to fulfill what was spoken through the prophet:
“Say*pn to Daughter Zion, ‘See,*ld your king comes to you, gentle*ln and riding on a donkey, and*ld on a colt, the foal of a donkey.’ ”
The*p disciples went and did as Jesus had instructed them.
They brought the donkey and the colt and placed their cloaks on them for Jesus to sit on.
A very large crowd spread their cloaks on the road, while others cut branches from the trees and spread them on the road.
The crowds that went ahead of him and those that followed shouted, “Hosanna*pn to the Son of David!” “Blessed*pn is he who comes in the name of the Lord!” “Hosanna*pn in the highest heaven!”
When*p Jesus entered Jerusalem, the whole city was stirred and asked, “Who is this?”
The*p crowds answered, “This is Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth in Galilee.”
Jesus at the Temple
Jesus*p entered the temple courts and drove out all who were buying and selling there. He overturned the tables of the money changers and the benches of those selling doves.
“It*r is*r written,”*r he said to them, “ ‘My*r house*r will*r be*r called*r a*r house*r of*r prayer,’*r but*r you*r are*r making*r it*r ‘a*r den*r of*r robbers.’”*r
The*p blind and the lame came to him at the temple, and he healed them.
But when the chief priests and the teachers of the law saw the wonderful things he did and the children shouting in the temple courts, “Hosanna to the Son of David,” they were indignant.

“Do*p you hear what these children are saying?” they asked him. “Yes,”*rp replied Jesus, “have*r you*r never*r read,*r “ ‘From*rpn the*r lips*r of*r children*r and*r infants*r you,*rld Lord,*r have*r called*r forth*r your*r praise’?”*r
And*p he left them and went out of the city to Bethany, where he spent the night.
Jesus Curses a Fig Tree
Early*p in the morning, as Jesus was on his way back to the city, he was hungry.
Seeing a fig tree by the road, he went up to it but found nothing on it except leaves. Then he said to it, “May*r you*r never*r bear*r fruit*r again!”*r Immediately the tree withered.
When*p the disciples saw this, they were amazed. “How did the fig tree wither so quickly?” they asked.

Jesus*p replied, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r if*r you*r have*r faith*r and*r do*r not*r doubt,*r not*r only*r can*r you*r do*r what*r was*r done*r to*r the*r fig*r tree,*r but*r also*r you*r can*r say*r to*r this*r mountain,*r ‘Go,*r throw*r yourself*r into*r the*r sea,’*r and*r it*r will*r be*r done.*r
If*r you*r believe,*r you*r will*r receive*r whatever*r you*r ask*r for*r in*r prayer.”*r
The Authority of Jesus Questioned

Jesus*p entered the temple courts, and, while he was teaching, the chief priests and the elders of the people came to him. “By what authority are you doing these things?” they asked. “And who gave you this authority?”
Jesus*p replied, “I*r will*r also*r ask*r you*r one*r question.*r If*r you*r answer*r me,*r I*r will*r tell*r you*r by*r what*r authority*r I*r am*r doing*r these*r things.*r

John’s*r baptism—where*r did*r it*r come*r from?*r Was*r it*r from*r heaven,*r or*r of*r human*r origin?”*r They*p discussed it among themselves and said, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will ask, ‘Then why didn’t you believe him?’
But if we say, ‘Of human origin’—we are afraid of the people, for they all hold that John was a prophet.”
So*p they answered Jesus, “We don’t know.” Then*p he said, “Neither*r will*r I*r tell*r you*r by*r what*r authority*r I*r am*r doing*r these*r things.*r
The Parable of the Two Sons
“What*rp do*r you*r think?*r There*r was*r a*r man*r who*r had*r two*r sons.*r He*r went*r to*r the*r first*r and*r said,*r ‘Son,*r go*r and*r work*r today*r in*r the*r vineyard.’*r
“ ‘I*rp will*r not,’*r he*r answered,*r but*r later*r he*r changed*r his*r mind*r and*r went.*r
“Then*rp the*r father*r went*r to*r the*r other*r son*r and*r said*r the*r same*r thing.*r He*r answered,*r ‘I*r will,*r sir,’*r but*r he*r did*r not*r go.*r

“Which*rp of*r the*r two*r did*r what*r his*r father*r wanted?”*r “The*p first,” they answered. Jesus*p said to them, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r the*r tax*r collectors*r and*r the*r prostitutes*r are*r entering*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r ahead*r of*r you.*r

For*r John*r came*r to*r you*r to*r show*r you*r the*r way*r of*r righteousness,*r and*r you*r did*r not*r believe*r him,*r but*r the*r tax*r collectors*r and*r the*r prostitutes*r did.*r And*r even*r after*r you*r saw*r this,*r you*r did*r not*r repent*r and*r believe*r him.*r
The Parable of the Tenants

“Listen*rp to*r another*r parable:*r There*r was*r a*r landowner*r who*r planted*r a*r vineyard.*r He*r put*r a*r wall*r around*r it,*r dug*r a*r winepress*r in*r it*r and*r built*r a*r watchtower.*r Then*r he*r rented*r the*r vineyard*r to*r some*r farmers*r and*r moved*r to*r another*r place.*r
When*r the*r harvest*r time*r approached,*r he*r sent*r his*r servants*r to*r the*r tenants*r to*r collect*r his*r fruit.*r
“The*rp tenants*r seized*r his*r servants;*r they*r beat*r one,*r killed*r another,*r and*r stoned*r a*r third.*r
Then*r he*r sent*r other*r servants*r to*r them,*r more*r than*r the*r first*r time,*r and*r the*r tenants*r treated*r them*r the*r same*r way.*r
Last*r of*r all,*r he*r sent*r his*r son*r to*r them.*r ‘They*r will*r respect*r my*r son,’*r he*r said.*r
“But*rp when*r the*r tenants*r saw*r the*r son,*r they*r said*r to*r each*r other,*r ‘This*r is*r the*r heir.*r Come,*r let’s*r kill*r him*r and*r take*r his*r inheritance.’*r
So*r they*r took*r him*r and*r threw*r him*r out*r of*r the*r vineyard*r and*r killed*r him.*r
“Therefore,*rp when*r the*r owner*r of*r the*r vineyard*r comes,*r what*r will*r he*r do*r to*r those*r tenants?”*r
“He*p will bring those wretches to a wretched end,” they replied, “and he will rent the vineyard to other tenants, who will give him his share of the crop at harvest time.”

Jesus*p said to them, “Have*r you*r never*r read*r in*r the*r Scriptures:*r “ ‘The*rpn stone*r the*r builders*r rejected*r has*rld become*r the*r cornerstone;*r the*rln Lord*r has*r done*r this,*r and*rld it*r is*r marvelous*r in*r our*r eyes’?*r
“Therefore*rp I*r tell*r you*r that*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r will*r be*r taken*r away*r from*r you*r and*r given*r to*r a*r people*r who*r will*r produce*r its*r fruit.*r
Anyone*r who*r falls*r on*r this*r stone*r will*r be*r broken*r to*r pieces;*r anyone*r on*r whom*r it*r falls*r will*r be*r crushed.”*r
When*p the chief priests and the Pharisees heard Jesus’ parables, they knew he was talking about them.
They looked for a way to arrest him, but they were afraid of the crowd because the people held that he was a prophet.
